II. 

INTRODUCTION

2.
Governance  has emerged  as Pakistan’s foremost development priority. Corruption  and
political  instability  in  the  1990s  have  resulted  in  waning  business  confidence,  lower  economic
growth, increasing poverty, and a serious undermining of state institutions and the rule of law.
Central  to  this  malaise  is  the  alienation  of  the  citizenry  from  the  state  and  a  feeling  of
disempowerment against abuse of power by officials.

3.
Central  to  the  Government's  commitment  to  governance  reforms  is  strengthening  the
rule  of  law  and  reforming  key  institutions.  The  local  government  plan,  put  into  effect  on  14
August 2001, has as one of its objectives to bring “justice to the doorstep” of the people. The
long-term  impact  of  these  reforms  is  uncertain,  but  the  present  Government's  commitment,  in
both  policy  rhetoric  and  practice,  and  in  the  broad-ranging  scope  of  the  reforms  suggests
readiness  to  confront  serious  constraints  to  reforms  that  have  eluded  Pakistan  since
Independence. The most serious constraints are found in the political culture, and in sanctions
and  incentives  bearing  on  the  judiciary,  police,  and  administration.  The  judiciary  has  been
repeatedly  compromised  by  political  practices,  and  has  not  garnered  the  necessary  degree  of
independence from the executive, especially in terms of securing an adequate and predictable
level of resourcing. Similarly, the police services remain affected by a colonial legacy that sets
them  in  an  oppressive  relationship  with  the  citizenry  as  the  police  are  forced  to  extract  non-
formal payments from citizens to secure even basic police services.

4.
Governance reforms in Pakistan have been opposed by powerful pro-status quo vested
interests. The severe fiscal deficit puts additional restraints on a reform agenda. But Pakistan's
long  term  economic  recovery  depends  on  the  effectiveness  of  governance  reforms.  The  AJP
addresses  some  of  the  most  fundamental  reforms  necessary  for  improved  governance,
including  greater  transparency  and  accountability  of  officials,  improved  public  access  to  basic
entitlements, and more predictable and adequate resourcing for the fundamental public good of
law  and  order.  The  agreement  on  the  AJP  Program  Loan  is  reflected  in  the  Government’s
Development Policy Letter and the attached Policy Matrix and Performance Review in Appendix
1.

III. 

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT

A. 

The Economy

Pakistan  faces  severe  macroeconomic  imbalances,  declining  economic  growth,  rising
6.
poverty, and underdeveloped human capital. During the 1990s, the fiscal deficit and the current
account  deficit  as  proportions  of  the  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  averaged  6.9  percent  and
4.5  percent,  respectively.  The  average  economic  growth  rate  decelerated  from  6.5  percent  in
the  1980s  to  5.4  percent  in  the  first  half  of  the  1990s,  and  to  3.6  percent  during  the  last  few
years. The incidence of poverty increased from less than 20 percent in the late-1980s to over 35
percent today.

During  FY2001,  the  Government  continued  to  pursue  macroeconomic  stabilization
7.
policies coupled with structural reform, and the GDP growth was estimated at nearly 2.6 percent
that year. In addition, the savings and investment rates, at less than 15 percent of GDP in 2001,
remained  low,  and  the  agriculture  sector  continued  to  dominate  the  economy.  Inflation,  as
measured by changes in the Consumer Price Index, was 4.4 percent in FY2001 as against 3.6
percent  in  FY2000.  The  higher  inflation  in  FY2001  is  mainly  attributable  to  an  increase  in
petroleum  prices.  The  drought  (which  ended  only  recently),  weak  external  demand,  falling
commodity prices, and persistently high world oil prices adversely affected Pakistan’s external
sector  performance.  Declining  unit  prices  of  Pakistan  exports  resulted  in  failure  to  meet  the
export  target  of  US$10  billion  estimated  for  FY2001.  The  budget  deficit  of  5.2  percent  for
FY2001 was the lowest fiscal deficit in 20 years. In FY2001, revenue collection increased by 12
percent. Despite this growth in tax collection, overall tax revenue collection in FY2001 was 10
percent lower than the target.

8.
Crises  in  the  management  of  public  finances  and  external  balances  dominated  the
economic  policy  agenda  in  Pakistan  during  the  1990s.  However,  despite  all  efforts,  and  three
International Monetary Fund (IMF) programs between 1988 and 1999, adequate progress was
not  made  in  addressing  the  macroeconomic  imbalances.  Frequent  changes  of  government
during  this  period  contributed  to  uneven  commitment  to  reform,  with  an  attendant  negative
impact on growth. The imposition of economic sanctions following the nuclear tests of May 1998
seriously affected an economy already weakened by a large public debt.

9.
Chronic fiscal and external deficits have resulted in accumulation of large domestic and
external debt. Total debt (both domestic and external) equaled 115 percent of GDP in FY2001,
and  interest  payments  on  total  debt  accounted  for  almost  50  percent  of  the  total  current
expenditure of the Government. Of Pakistan’s “twin” debt problem, the external debt is the more
critical issue for short to medium term economic management. In FY 1998, the ratio of external

B. 

Poverty and Justice in Pakistan

12.
It  is  generally  accepted  that  poverty  fell  through  the  1980s,  but  rose  again  over  the
1990s to 30-34 percent of the population.5 Poverty in Pakistan appears to exhibit seven features
of  direct  relevance  to  the  approach  and  rationale  of  the  AJP.  First,  income  distribution  is
relatively  equal  compared  with  countries  of  similar  income  level.6  Second,  although  the
incidence of poverty is high, turnover among the poor is also rapid. In one study, 46-51 percent
of households left the category of “poverty” from one year to the next. Rather than focusing on
the symptoms of poverty (such as income gap or social sector indicators), this suggests a focus
on the probable causes of entry and exit into poverty. Third, although rural areas appear to have
a  higher  incidence  of  poverty  than  urban  areas,  several  studies  report  a  trend  towards  the
opposite, partly as a result of rapid urbanization (now 36 percent), which is high for South Asia
(28  percent).  Fourth,  a  large  proportion  of  the  poor  are  dependent  on  informal  sector  wage
labor.

13.
The fifth and sixth features of poverty in Pakistan provide further focus on vulnerability.
While  relatively  egalitarian  in  terms  of  “income  poverty,”  the  capacity  of  the  poor  to  access
public  entitlements–like  political  processes  or  goods  and  services  that  determine  human
development–contrasts  strikingly  with  that  of  the  rich.  For  instance,  literacy,  which  is  critically
important in awareness of and access to entitlements, is highly unequal. There are tremendous
disparities in human development (defined as enlarging people's choices in a way that enables
them to lead longer, healthier and fuller lives). Most key indicators, like infant mortality, fertility,
population growth, literacy rates and primary school enrollment remain low compared with the

1.

Poverty, Governance, and Vulnerability

14.
Poverty  reflects  social  and  political  processes  that  are  mediated  through  a  range  of
institutions.  Typically,  institutional  “failure”  is  generalized  as  a  “problem  of  governance.”  While
Pakistan  enjoyed  significant  annual  GDP  growth  for  over  50  years  (1947-1997),  the  control  of
political  power  and  government  by  a  small  elite  ensured  that  institutionalized  decision  making
was  irrelevant  to  the  wider  needs  of  the  population  and,  as  a  consequence,  poverty  has
remained widespread.7

15.
The existence of high-quality public institutions that mediate people's access to services
essential  for  human,  physical,  and  financial  capital  is  as  important  as  the  assets  themselves.
The capacity of public institutions indeed strongly influences whether a state is “developmental”
or  “predatory”,  a  key  theme  in  the  AJP.  Understanding  the  relationship  among  “governance,”
poverty,  and  vulnerability  from  the  viewpoint  of  the  poor  highlights  two  points  relevant  to  the
rationale for the AJP. First, while poverty manifests as material deprivation–hunger, the lack of
food, shelter, clothing–the poor also highlight common psychological and political dimensions to
poverty–lack of power and voice; feelings of dependency, shame, and humiliation. Poor people
highlight  lack  of  access  to  basic  infrastructure  and  services.  But  whereas  official  accounts  of
poverty  highlight  the  difference  between  rich  and  poor  in  indicators  of  educational,  health,  or
other standards of attainment, the poor rarely have such a static view of what is required in their
lives. Education is valued, for instance, but only if it offers an escape from poverty, not in its own
right.  Lack  of  access  to  affordable,  effective  health  care  is  dreaded,  not  just  as  a  source  of  ill
health,  important  though  that  is,  but  as  a  source  of  vulnerability  and,  ultimately,  destitution.
Finally, while the poor are concerned about lack of income, they frequently attribute this to the
constraints they face in managing their assets (human, material, social, political), through which
they cope with their vulnerability.

16.
Second,  most  poor  people  recognize  that  the  state  has  responsibilities  to  provide
affordable,  effective,  and  equitable  public  goods  and  services.  They  feel  the  government  has
failed  to  deliver  and  indeed  that  their  interactions  with  local  state  institutions  are  marked  by
rudeness,  humiliation,  harassment,  and  corruption.  The  poor  often  perceive  their  interactions
with these agencies as increasing their vulnerability to erosion of important household, political,
civil, natural resource, and social assets. Globally, the impact of a brutalizing police force and a
corrupt  judiciary  is,  for  instance,  remarked  by  the  poor  far  more  often  than  is  attended  to  in
official accounts of indicators and causes of poverty focusing, for instance, on access to health
or  education.8  These  intermediating  institutions,  in  particular  those  of  the  local  state,  are
particularly  demoralizing  for  the  poor,  who  already  feel  defenseless  against  the  power  of  the
state and the elite.

17.
In  most  aspects  of  their  lives,  the  poor  rely  on  informal  justice  and  dispute  resolution
forum  that  in  some  respects  have  been  more  effective  than  formal  mechanisms.  In  Pakistan,

most  popular  forums  for  dispute  resolution.9  Local  panchayats  (traditional  council  of  elders/

and  their  link  to  local  communities  and  families.  Panchayats  tend  not  to  be  known  for  their
commitment  to  the  truth  or  ability  to  avoid  vested  interests.  While  the  informal  legal  system
offers  cheaper  resolution  of  disputes,  it  is  more  difficult  to  enforce  decisions,  and  its
deliberations are frequently manipulated by local elites (i.e., members of the dominant faction);
as a result the panchayats are unable to hear both parties on an equal basis. Furthermore, the
informal  legal  system  is  insufficient  for  adequate  market-based  economic  growth,  and
constrains  significant  foreign  direct  investment  as  well  as  the  growth  of  small-  and  medium-
sized enterprises.10

18.
The  vulnerable  poor  are  especially  affected  by  their  relations  with  a  dysfunctional  and
predatory local state. It is at this level that the connection between vulnerability and governance
has its greatest meaning. It is at this interface that dispensation of justice in the wider sense fails
and  disempowers,  particularly  the  poor.  Vulnerability  is  exacerbated  by  the  everyday
harassment, underperformance, exclusion, and denial of basic rights by public officials of people
who  are  disadvantaged  by  virtue  of  gender,  ethnicity,  or  economic  or  political  power.  This
source of vulnerability is marked in three aspects of the lives of the poor. Vulnerability is much
increased  by  local  officials  responsible  for  licensing  and  regulating  economic  activities  who
typically extract rent from informal sector workers. Further, and well known, the vulnerability of
the poor is continually reaffirmed by the corruption of local cadre/officials that hampers access
to public goods and services – health, education, land management, etc. Finally, the failure of
government institutions to provide law and order and security is a function of the existent police,
legal, and judicial structures.

C. 

Government Objectives and Strategy

51.
The  Government’s  commitment  to  governance  reforms  is  based  on  five  fundamentals:
devolution  of  political  power,  decentralization  of  administrative  authority,  deconcentration  of
management functions, diffusion of the power-authority nexus, and distribution of resources to
the district level. It aims to “ensure that the genuine interests of the people are served and their
rights  safeguarded”  and  to  create  “an  enabling  environment  in  which  people  can  start
participating in community welfare and be the masters of their own destiny.” 23  To hold the local
bureaucracy accountable, district ombudsmen will be appointed. Resolution of private disputes
through  means  other  than  the  courts  will  be  encouraged  through  new  institutions,  Masalihat
Anjuman  (MAs)  or  Conciliation  Committees  that  build  on  traditional  dispute  resolution
institutions  such  as  the  panchayat. The  powerful  office  of  the  district  commissioner  has  been
abolished so that there is no concentration of executive and judicial powers. Many of the powers
exercised  by  these  officers  will  now  go  to  the  judiciary  and  other  line  departments,  while  the
executive magistracy will be placed under the judiciary. Separate criminal and civil courts will be
established  at  the  lowest  level,  and  the  capacity  of  the  subordinate  judiciary  to  deal  with  the
criminal work will be enhanced. These changes in the district police and administration have the
potential to profoundly redefine and positively influence the relationship between the citizen and
the state.

V. 

THE PROGRAM

63.
The  pro-poor  rationale  for  the  AJP  centers  on  the  concepts  of  vulnerability,  access  to
justice, entitlements, and assets. Vulnerability is understood as a function of insecurity of access
to  key  sets  of  material,  social,  political,  and  environmental  assets,  which  expose  individuals,
households and communities to increased or disproportionate risk of impoverishment. Justice is
understood  as  a  function  of  the  relationship  between  institutions  responsible  for  delivering
entitlements (public goods and services) predictably, affordably, and accountably and the ability
of  the  poor  to  secure  and  sustain  their  access  to  key  sets  of  assets.  Efforts  to  limit  the
vulnerability of the poor to the vagaries of systems of administrative, political, civil, and criminal
justice  are  at  least  as  important  as  macroeconomic  performance  in  poverty  reduction.  Further
the  present  legal  framework  and  the  performance  of  the  judicial  institutions  responsible
significantly  constrain  market-based  economic  growth  and,  in  particular,  hinder  foreign  direct
investment as well as the growth of small and medium-sized enterprises.

64.
Reforms  in  the  administrative,  police  and  judicial  sectors  have  until  now  proven
particularly  difficult.  However,  the  present  context  for  the  AJP  is  conducive.  First,  the
Government has already taken same very significant steps to demonstrate its commitment to all
the  policy,  legal  and  structural  reforms  listed  in  the  Policy  Matrix.  Second,  government
commitment to devolution and the creation of democratically elected local governments ensures
that the judicial and police reforms supported under the AJP are nested in a wider framework of
prior Government commitment. Finally, government policy acknowledges that these reforms will
require thorough-going changes in public sector budget planning and expenditure management,
including  the  introduction  and  enforcement  of  systems  for  better  accountability  of  public
servants and officials responsible for fiscal and human resource management.

D. 

Social and Environmental Issues

1. 

Social Issues

89.
The AJP is a key part of nationwide efforts to positively influence the exercise of political,
administrative and judicial power so as to improve the accessibility of public entitlements for all
citizens, but in particular the poor, women and minorities. Although no adverse social impact is
anticipated  (Poverty  Impact  Assessment  –  Appendix  4),  the  AJP  will  actively  prompt  critical
public  and  professional  debate  about  important  social  issues  and  will  be  one  modest  part  of
larger efforts to transform the culture of governance in Pakistan.

90.
The concentration of political and economic power has led the state to promote parochial
interests,  which  has  reduced  its  effectiveness  at  responding  to  the  needs  of  a  very  diverse
population. Corruption, nepotism, and personalized decisionmaking have dominated the political
scene;  and  accountability  processes  have  been  both  ineffectual  and  selective.  Elites,  acting
through  the  executive,  have  contributed  to  the  dramatic  erosion  of  democratic  process  and
accountability.  The  judiciary  has  too  often  been  called  upon  to  adjudicate  essentially  political
disputes. This has strained its independence and raised concerns regarding its politicization and
legitimacy.

91.
Although the AJP will act on a range of “supply” side constraints to the delivery of justice
by  police  and  the  judiciary,  its  corresponding  focus  on  accountability,  sanctions  and
performance through legal empowerment will raise sensitive cultural, social, and political issues.
According to this empowerment-oriented definition of access to justice, awareness and literacy
involve  building  people’s  appreciation  of  their  rights  and  the  law;  their  ability  to  act  on  legal

 knowledge or to assert their rights individually or collectively; and their capacity to mobilize for
change.  This  approach  will  focus  on  disadvantaged  populations  who  most  need  legal
knowledge and ways to use it.

Dear Mr. Chino,

Good  governance  is  an  integral  part  of  the  Government  of  Pakistan’s  Three-Year
Poverty  Reduction  Program  announced  in  February  2001.  As  part  of  its  strategy  to  address
governance  issues  in  Pakistan,  the  Government  has  launched  an  anticorruption  drive  and
started  implementation  of  a  devolution  plan  that  will  enhance  accountability  of  public  officials
and  establish  more  democratic  and  equitable  society.  Local  government  elections  have  been
successfully  completed  and  local  government  structures  are  being  established  in  accordance
with  the  Local  Government  Ordinance  recently  enacted  by  each  province.  With  devolution,
citizens will have more democratic control over delivery of public services at the local level and
the new government structures will be more transparent and accountable to them.

Central  to  good  governance  in  Pakistan  is  strengthening  the  rule  of  law  and  ensuring
access to justice, particularly by the vulnerable poor. The Government acknowledges that this
requires  a  number  of  concrete  steps  that  create  a  policy  and  legal  framework  for  an
independent and functional judiciary, a professional police force that serves the rule of law, and
a  system  of  administrative  justice  that  can  effectively  and  efficiently  deal  with  citizens’
grievances. The Government also needs to work with civil society to empower people to enforce
their  legal  rights  and  develop  public-private  partnerships  for  this  purpose  as  well  as  to  raise
standards  of  an  independent  legal  profession.  Persistent  inadequate  budgetary  allocations  for
the police and the judiciary have contributed to a weakening rule of law in Pakistan. Any serious
reform effort must, therefore, ensure adequate budgetary allocations and make up for the years
of neglect through greater attention to human resource development and investment in physical
infrastructure. Only a comprehensive reform package that seeks to address issues of legal and
policy  framework,  institutional  capacity  and  incentives,  and  sustainable  financing  based  on
efficient  use  of  resources  can  initiate  a  process  to  strengthen  the  rule  of  law  in  Pakistan.  The
Government  has  accordingly  formulated  a  comprehensive  Access  to  Justice  Program  (AJP)
with  the  assistance  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  carry  out  systemic  judicial  and
police reforms to strengthen the rule of law to the advantage of ordinary citizens, especially the
poor. The following key issues and areas will be addressed under AJP through lynch-pin policy
reforms as detailed in the policy matrix (Attachment 1). In addition, a number of milestones and
complementary  actions  will  be  taken  as  outlined  in  the  performance  review  (Attachment  2)  to
support  the  lynch-pin  policy  initiatives  in  the  policy  matrix.  During  each  performance  review,
progress  in  achieving  the  policy  initiatives  will  be  monitored,  and  the  milestones  and
complementary actions will be carefully calibrated to respond to a dynamic reform process.

The Government affirms the constitutional provisions relating to the independence of the
judiciary. Accordingly, the Government has taken a historical decision to fulfill the constitutional
mandate  of  separating  the  judiciary  from  the  executive  by  placing  all  executive  magistrates
under the control and supervision of the judiciary. The Government also recognizes that in the
past inadequate attention has been given to administration of justice and judicial policymaking.
Accordingly,  the  mandate  of  the  Law  Commission  will  be  expanded  together  with  its
composition to include the chief justices of the High Courts as ex-officio members. The reformed

Law  Commission  will  be  provided  adequate  financial  and  human  resources  to  carry  out  its
mandate.  In  addition,  a  national  judicial  policymaking  body  will  also  be  established  that  is
acceptable to the Chief  Justices of  the superior courts. The Government is aware that judicial
independence has in the past been undermined by, among other things, inadequate budgetary
allocations. Recurrent non-salary budgets for the judiciary have declined in almost all provinces
while  the  physical  infrastructure  for  the  subordinate  courts  has  deteriorated.  Accordingly,  the
Federal  and  provincial  governments  are  committed  to  augmenting  budgetary  allocations  to
make  the  judiciary  an  effective  institution  and  to  ensuring  adequate  budgetary  allocations
through  the  development  of  a  medium-term  budget/expenditure  framework  for  the  judiciary.
Salary and terms and conditions of the subordinate judiciary will also be reviewed. To ensure a
modicum  of  financial  stability  in  key  institutions,  the  Government  has  decided  to  establish  the
Access  to  Justice  Development  Fund  (AJDF)  that  will,  among  other  things,  support  the
subordinate courts, the Law Commission, and the Federal Judicial Academy. The Government
also affirms its commitment to filling all judicial posts in a timely manner within 120 days of any
vacancy.

The slow pace of litigation in courts together with the high costs of litigation undermine
public confidence in the judicial system. Provision of justice in an expeditious manner and with
as least cost as possible is, therefore, a primary concern of the Government. Accordingly, the
Government  will  pass  legislation  to  establish  small  causes  courts  for  resolution  of  minor
disputes  through  summary  procedure,  together  with  amendments  to  the  Family  Courts  Act  to
ensure speedier resolution of all family disputes. The law relating to writs of habeas corpus in
cases  of  unlawful  confinement  will  also  be  reviewed.  The  High  Courts  have  began
experimenting with delay reduction techniques based on a modern case management system to
reduce  the  backlog  of  pending  cases.  Currently,  many  of  the  subordinate  court  judges  handle
both civil and criminal cases. In order to facilitate improved case docket management, civil and
criminal cases will be separated and assigned to different courts so that individual judges with
handle either criminal or civil cases. Similarly, separate full-time benches will be established in
the Sindh and Lahore High Courts for commercial cases. In addition, court administration will be
improved through a phased program that will result in induction of professional managers and
use of modern management techniques in the court system to ensure efficient use of resources.
Improved case and docket management cuts across the judiciary, prosecution services, and the
prisons. A comprehensive information technology plan will be developed for this purpose and its
implementation will commence under the AJP.

In  addition,  the  Government  also  recognizes  the  need  to  promote  alternative  dispute
resolution (ADR). For this purpose, the recently enacted Local Government Ordinances provide
for establishment of Anjuman-e-Masalihat (conciliatory bodies). In addition, the High Courts will
also  promote  use  of  court-annexed  ADR  as  part  of  their  delay  reduction  strategies.  In  this
respect,  the  High  Courts  have  agreed  to  review  procedural  rules  to  facilitate  ADR.  The  legal
framework for ADR will also be strengthened through a thorough review of the Arbitration Act to
bring  it  in  conformity  with  international  standards.  This  will  contribute  to  creating  a  favorable
environment for both domestic and foreign direct investment.

Delivery  of  justice,  however,  is  not  confined  to  the  courts.  Many  of  the  public’s
grievances arise from maladministration by government officials. The Government is, therefore,
committed  to  improving  the  functioning  of  the  federal  and  provincial  ombudsmen  while
establishing offices of district ombudsmen under the Local Government Ordinances. Working of
the  ombudsmen  offices  will  be  reviewed  and  new  appellate  procedures  introduced  to  reduce

delay. The Government will also review existing legislation to ensure greater independence and
security of tenure for the ombudsmen.

Beyond  institutional  change,  the  rule  of  law  assumes  an  active  citizenry  aware  of  its
rights  and  capable  of  enforcing  them.  The  Government  supports  a  series  of  initiatives  to
improve the status of the poor in particular, and the citizens in general as regards their dealings
with  the  state.  Accordingly,  the  Government  will  introduce  the  freedom  of  information  act  to
allow ready access by citizens to information that affects their rights while at the same time, it
will commence publishing simplified explanations of new federal and provincial laws in Urdu. To
strengthen  rule  of  law  and  protect  citizens  from  arbitrary  executive  actions,  the  immunity
enjoyed  by  civil  servants  will  be  reviewed  to  make  them  liable  for  torts  committed  against
citizens  as  envisaged  under  Article  212(2)  of  the  Constitution.  In  addition,  a  law  will  be
promulgated  so  that  rules,  regulations,  and  circulars  having  the  effect  of  law  only  shall  be
published in the official gazette. Contempt and defamation laws will also be reviewed to strike a
balance  between  freedom  of  expression,  and  sanctity  of  the  courts  and  the  rights  of  the
individual.  To  protect  citizens  as  consumers,  consumer  protection  legislation  in  place  for
Islamabad will be implemented and country-wide legislation will also be introduced.

A  country  such  as  Pakistan  cannot  sustain  a  state-financed  legal  aid  system.  Yet,  the
needs of the poor for justice must be met. In the first instance, they must be made aware of their
rights, and ways must be found to ensure that they enjoy equal protection of law as mandated
by  the  Constitution.  Beyond  the  policy  initiatives  outlined  above  to  improve  the  state-citizen
interface,  other  steps  must  be  taken  to  ensure  that  the  poor  in  particular,  and  the  citizens
generally  are  legally  empowered.  This  requires  public-private  partnerships  and  active
involvement  of  civil  society.  To  promote  such  initiatives,  a  portion  of  the  ADJF  will  support  a
variety of civil society legal empowerment initiatives from legal literacy to advocacy and public
interest litigation. Under the AJP, citizen orientation of courts and other institutions will also be
promoted. In courts, information centers will be established in partnership with civil society and
the  bar.  In  addition,  improved  administration  within  the  judicial  system,  greater  transparency
through  publication  of  annual  reports  by  the  High  Courts  and  holding  of  annual  judicial
conferences  will  promote  greater  citizen  focus.  To  further  improve  the  legal  position  of  the
vulnerable poor, a study of laws adversely affecting the poor will be carried out to identify legal
reform  initiatives  for  the  poor.  This  will  include  a  study  of  the  rights  of  the  poor  to  natural
resources and the environment. Environmental justice will be strengthened by establishment of
environmental  tribunals  and  ensuring  that  separate  individuals  head  the  environmental
departments and environmental protection agencies to eliminate any conflict of interest.

A long-term challenge for access to justice relates to improving human resources within
the judiciary and the police. This requires a multi-faceted approach. To encourage law schools
to  raise  their  standards,  the  ADJF  will  support  innovations  in  legal  education  by  existing  law
schools. In addition, the Government will work with the private sector and existing public sector
institutions to establish centers of excellence in legal education. More immediately, the training
of judges is of paramount importance. For this purpose, the Federal Judicial Academy has been
further  strengthened  through  increase  in  faculty  positions  and  allocation  of  greater  resources
through  the  AJDF.  Improvement  in  human  resources  is,  however,  not  simply  a  function  of
training. Therefore, the Government is committed to reviewing terms and conditions of service
of subordinate judges while at the same time, working with the High Courts to institute improved
incentive  systems  for  the  subordinate  judiciary,  including  introduction  of  revised  performance
standards  and  transparent  recruitment  procedures  for  the  subordinate  judiciary.  The  judiciary

level annual judicial conferences.

As part of its commitment to improved governance, the Government has also initiated a
process  of  comprehensive  reform  of  the  police.  In  the  first  stage,  amendments  have  been
introduced  to  existing  legislation  to  depoliticize  the  police  force  by  establishing  public  safety
commissions  at  the  federal,  provincial  and  district  levels,  and  their  composition  and  selection
procedures  will  ensure  adequate  political  neutrality  to  ensure  rule  of  law.  Various  legal  and
administrative measures have been taken and a plan is to be prepared to enhance institutional
performance  of  the  police,  including  forensic  facilities,  modernizing  and  improving  criminal
records  and  investigation  capacity,  policing  capacity  and  training.  Under  further  legislation,
accountability  of  the  police  will  also  be  enhanced  through  independent  police  authorities  and
establishment of independent prosecution agencies in each of the provinces. As in the case of
the  judiciary,  human  resource  development  will  be  important,  with  particular  focus  on  training
and  introduction  of  improved  incentive  systems  that  promote  greater  citizen  orientation  and
respect for human rights and gender sensitization.

The  Government  is  acutely  aware  of  marginalization  of  women  regarding  their  legal
entitlements.  With  respect  to  the  judiciary  and  the  police,  the  Government  is  committed  to  a
policy of promoting greater gender sensitization, while actively promoting recruitment of women
within the judiciary through, among other things, revising service rules to remove gender biases
and facilitating induction of more women judges. In addition, the AJDF will provide resources for
civil  society  groups  to  raise  awareness  among  women  about  their  legal  entitlements  and  to
assist women to enforce their rights. In addition, the Government will support activities to forge
consensus on laws and policies to improve the status of women.

rule  of  law  in  Pakistan  and  make  a  qualitative  difference  to  governance.  The  AJP  comprises

1.
The  five  broad  outputs  expected  from  the  Access  to  Justice  Program  (AJP)  are  (i)
improvement of policy and legal frameworks to remove major constraints on public rights (such
as access to information, redress, and public accountability), commerce and investment, judicial
independence,  and  depoliticization  of  the  police,  among  others;  and  improved  accountability
and  performance  of  public  sector  performance  in  delivering  services;  (ii)  greater  efficiency,
timeliness,  and  effectiveness  in  judiciary  and  policy  administration;  (iii)  greater  equity  and
accessibility    of  judicial  and  police  services  for  the  poor;  (iv)  improved  allocation  of  fiscal  and
human  resources  required  for  judicial  and  police  reforms;  and  (v)  greater  transparency  and
accountability  in  performance  of  the  judiciary  and  police.  Collectively  these  are  analyzed  in
terms  of  their  anticipated  impacts  on  the  labor  market,  prices  of  goods  and  services,  public
expenditures, and access to public goods and services.

2.
Impact on Labor Market. On the macro level, the AJP’s impact on the labor market is
expected  to  be  positive,  as  the  constraints  will  be  diminished  for  market-based  economic
growth.  In  particular,  increases  are  expected  in  foreign  direct  investment  and  the  accelerated
development  of  small-  and  medium-sized  enterprises,  which  are  engines  of  job  creation.  The
direct  short-term  impact  of  the  AJP  on  the  labor  market,  however,    will  not  be  as  significant.
Although  the  AJP  will  provide  some  additional  budgeted  positions  such  as  lower  court  judges
and police officers, their numbers will be small in relation to the entire formal job market. In the
informal job market, an indirect impact will be the loss of income for existing rent seekers who
are able to facilitate judicial and police services under the current system.

3.
Impact on Prices of Goods and Services. On the macro level, the AJP is expected to
